ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn and read about the general trends in the development of 18th century Russian literature, poetry, and drama.
Basically Everything! I knew nothing about this fascinating period and its literature. Jinyi did a great job in presenting this, sometimes dull, material in a fun and interactive way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths- you cover a wide range of material and a lot of great secondary sources on it weakness- could have a gone more in depth on some of the texts but natural that this isn't possible when trying to cover the entire century

I loved that Jinyi made us write reading responses, and his attention to every one of them. They were extremely helpful memos for the exam! I also loved the versification reform exercise- it was a super fun way to teach a really technical and dull material. The division into presentation was also excellent.
The course was a low key survey, which was good in that I could have an overview of an important topic in the field, but it inevitably could not deal with all the topics in depth.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested in 18th century literature then this course will give you a great background to then apply your knowledge on the topic in more depth. Overall, a nice class with a great professor

Since this is a mandatory course we all have to take it. Yet, I think that anyone interested in Russian culture, should have some knowledge about this formative period. Thus, I will recommend it even for those who don't have to take the course.
